content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.

Here is the function you requested in Julia:
```
function audi_filter(df_cars::DataFrame)
 # Filter the DataFrame to only include rows with manufacturer "audi" and model "a4" or "a4 quattro"
 filtered_df = filter(:manufacturer => x -> x == "audi", :model => x -> x == "a4" || x == "a4 quattro", df_cars)

 # Add a new column audi_a4_type with value true for all rows
 filtered_df[:audi_a4_type] = true

 # Return the resulting DataFrame
 return filtered_df
end
```
You can use this function by passing your `df_cars` DataFrame as an argument like this:
```
filtered_audi_df = audi_filter(df_cars)
```
The resulting `filtered_audi_df` DataFrame will contain only the rows with manufacturer "audi" and model "a4" or "a4 quattro", and it will have a new column `audi_a4_type` with value `true` across all rows.
